Literature Review: Fermented foods have been an integral part of human diets for millennia, offering unique flavors, extended shelf-life, and enhanced nutritional value. The microbiomes responsible for these transformations have recently become the subject of intense scientific scrutiny, with researchers seeking to understand the complex ecological and evolutionary processes that shape microbial communities in fermented foods. This literature review explores the current state of knowledge regarding microbiome assembly in fermented foods, focusing on three case studies: surface-ripened cheese, sourdough starters, and fermented vegetables.The study of microbial communities in fermented foods has been revolutionized by the advent of high-throughput sequencing technologies. These tools have allowed researchers to map the diversity and dynamics of microbial populations across various fermentation processes. Wolfe et al. (2014) conducted a comprehensive survey of cheese rind microbiomes, revealing intricate patterns of bacterial and fungal diversity across different cheese types and aging conditions. Their work highlighted the importance of environmental factors in shaping microbial community composition and succession.In the realm of sourdough fermentation, De Vuyst et al. (2017) provided insights into the complex interplay between lactic acid bacteria and yeasts that characterize these microbial ecosystems. Their research emphasized the role of metabolic interactions and environmental parameters in driving community assembly and stability over time. Similarly, Harth et al. (2016) investigated the microbial ecology of fermented vegetables, demonstrating how initial raw material composition and fermentation conditions influence the trajectory of community development.The assembly of microbial communities in fermented foods can be understood through the lens of four fundamental ecological processes: dispersal, selection, diversification, and drift. Dispersal, the movement of microorganisms between environments, plays a crucial role in introducing diversity to fermentation systems. Bokulich and Mills (2013) demonstrated how production environments serve as reservoirs for microbial inocula, influencing the initial composition of fermented food microbiomes.Selection acts as a powerful force in shaping microbial communities, with environmental conditions and interspecies interactions driving the relative abundance of different taxa. Dugat-Bony et al. (2016) explored how pH, salt concentration, and nutrient availability in cheese ecosystems select for specific microbial populations, leading to the development of characteristic flavor profiles. In sourdough systems, Gänzle and Ripari (2016) elucidated how the interplay between temperature, hydration, and fermentation time selects for particular combinations of lactic acid bacteria and yeasts.Diversification within fermented food microbiomes occurs through both ecological and evolutionary mechanisms. Stefanovic et al. (2017) investigated how horizontal gene transfer and adaptive mutations contribute to the emergence of new strains with enhanced fermentation capabilities in lactic acid bacteria. This process of microbial evolution can lead to the development of unique, locally adapted strains that contribute to the terroir of traditional fermented products.Drift, the random changes in population sizes due to chance events, can also play a role in shaping microbial communities, particularly in small or isolated fermentation systems. However, its impact is often overshadowed by the strong selective pressures present in most fermented food environments.Understanding these ecological and evolutionary processes provides new avenues for managing and optimizing fermented food production. Cocolin et al. (2020) proposed a framework for applying ecological principles to the design of starter cultures, aiming to enhance product quality and consistency. By manipulating environmental conditions and inoculation strategies, producers can guide the assembly of desired microbial communities.The integration of in situ sequencing surveys with in vitro experimental models has proven particularly valuable in elucidating the mechanisms of microbiome assembly. Wolfe et al. (2016) developed a cheese rind model system that allowed for controlled manipulation of environmental parameters, providing insights into the drivers of microbial succession in these complex ecosystems. Similar approaches have been applied to sourdough and vegetable fermentations, offering a more mechanistic understanding of community dynamics.As our knowledge of fermented food microbiomes continues to expand, new challenges and opportunities emerge. The application of meta-omics approaches, combining metagenomics with metatranscriptomics and metabolomics, promises to provide a more holistic view of microbial community function and interactions. Additionally, the potential for leveraging fermented food microbiomes to enhance human health through the modulation of the gut microbiota represents an exciting frontier in microbiome research.In conclusion, the study of microbiome assembly in fermented foods represents a fascinating intersection of food science, microbiology, ecology, and evolution. By applying ecological and evolutionary frameworks to these ancient food production systems, researchers are gaining new insights into the processes that generate microbial diversity and functionality. This knowledge has the potential to revolutionize fermented food production, leading to enhanced quality, consistency, and innovation in this important sector of the food industry.
